DialogueLine.dialogue: easy peasy
DialogueLine.speaker: Darock

DialogueLine.dialogue: plop
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Salut wesh wesh yo [PP]!!
DialogueLine.speaker: Ratchet

DialogueLine.dialogue: Repaint()
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Salut !
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: wehs !
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Yolop
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: bloubloup
DialogueLine.speaker: Ratchet

DialogueLine.dialogue: wapwapwap
DialogueLine.speaker: Ratchet

DialogueLine.dialogue: [When you enter the tavern, you spot Agna directly. She’s sitting in the back of the tavern. You can’t help but notice that she’s frantically glancing at every person in the bar. You walk to her.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: Hello.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Hi.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Good morning.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [Agna stares at you silently with a cruel grin] I recognize you now. You’ve bought some venison from me last week. You looked… Different.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: Acknowledge her
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: You’re strong for a woman
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Yes. And you’re the Fear Monger, the one that defeated Rarbar Steel Fists in single combat. I heard you ripped his heart off his ribcage and fed him. I think that’s impressive.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Maybe. And you looked way sexier on your pictures, but you don’t see me complaining ! But I recognised you anyway, Fear Monger. You’re strong for a woman.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Hello.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Hi.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Good morning.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [Hearing the name « Fear Monger », the men in the tavern exchange frightful looks. Slowly, they all begin to leave their sits, discreetly tiptoeing to the front door. ]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: In the flesh, yes. It’s a fitting surname, judging by the reaction of these poor fools. But you’re still here, and you don’t seem to be afraid. You must have accomplished great things yourself. Tell me about your exploits.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [Surprised, the bartender looks around, and when his eyes meet Agna’s, he lets out a little squeak. He hastily brings a keg, mumbling muffled excuses, and leaves the tavern. You’re alone in this. Agna has observed all this mouvement with a smirk of pride.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: Overstate your achievements
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: She’s wrong
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Yes, actually, I have. I was a mercenary for 10 years, so I’ve fought and won many battles. I once drove 5 men to cowardly take their own life by just looking threateningly at them during the battle of […].
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She’s wrong. The ferocious light in her eyes made you piss yourself 3 times already. You feel the urge to leave, right now. As she stares at you, obviously waiting for your answer, you carefully observe the inside of the tavern, waiting for the right occasion to flee. Do you distract her ? How ?]
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Tell her the truth
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: I have not done such things as you have. But I was a good fighter. There was once an ancient rivalry between my family and the barbarians of Brak. We used to meet once a year, for the spring equinox.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: We’d organize a single combat, with champion from both families. I used to be my family’s representative. I won for 5 years in a row, until the grudge was settled. The winner had the right to take all of the loser’s newborn. I put their heads on spikes to remind them of our power.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [Maybe throwing your sword at her and running through the window ? You sigh, count to three and jump out of the tavern. Alone at her table, Agna frowns and lets a faint grown. Then, sighing, she pours herself a pint of beer.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: I find it hard to believe. You’re imaginative, I guess… But you’ll find I hate liars. [She really does. The pumping vein on her forehead makes you shake a little]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: You may not have decimated a whole clan, not everyone can brag about such an accomplishment, but you certainly do have respect for our ways. I appreciate that in a person.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: I like it here
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: I agree with you
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: The first time I arrived to your camp, I was really astonished by the oblivious customs of your people. Have all of you forgotten the thrill of the fight, the freedom of nomadism ?
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: It’s also nice to sleep in a bed and rest from battle from time to time. We’ve developed a real civilization here. We have water supplies, livestock and the craftsmen can have a place to work. We had to change our ways if we wanted to improve our existences.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: You are right. We should have kept our traditions alive. But then again, we can’t go back. We have to keep remembering the glorious past and try to teach our youth about the old ways.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: What you call civilization I call weakness. But I also see what you mean. You don’t have to suffer through the winters, and the young can eat their fill. I just wish we could live up to our ancestor’s glory. It angers me that we’re forgetting about them.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: I’m glad you share my views. But I also understand what you mean. We can’t go back now. It’s too late. Let us hope that one day, the others will understand our kind does not belong in little houses planting artichokes all day.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: You talk like your way of life has changed a lot coming here. How was your first clan like ?
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: What do you do now, with the truce going on ? Are you a merchant ?
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: My first clan was not like yours. We were always moving. Our ways were way harder than yours. Especially for the children. The ones who weren’t strong enough were given to Korm as an offering of blood. But even then, I wasn’t free. My mother was part of the craftsmen guild. I was her apprentice. I didn’t like this life. I didn’t wanted to forge swords, but to slice through flesh with them.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She looks right in your eyes, looking for a hint that you’re trying to mock her] You don’t know about my shameful enterprise ? I thought the entire tribe knew about it. I… I knit. I’ve always loved knitting. As a child, I was hiding in our tent to make my mother everything I could : scarves, pommel ornaments… I even did a blanket I embroidered with our tribe’s arms.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: When our clan got attacked by a group of raiders in the midst of the harshest winter we’d ever had, not many did survive. That was our chance to leave. But when we arrived here, my mother and I had to prove our value. We always had to. Even when I came back from my solo raid after the annihilation of the Stone Prophet Clan, it wasn’t enough.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She’s looking a bit uncomfortable telling you that. You can tell by the way she’s playing with the pommel of her sword under the table, and the fact that she’s avoiding your gaze] But I’ve been discovered once. Some brats in our tribe stole one of my works.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: It was a beautiful hat with a cute little pompom and a feather I had taken from the pet eagle of the Lagar’s chief. Several hours of work. I was livid. They paid for it. [She grins, and you fear what she’ll say next] They tried to shame me for my craft. I added them to it. I used their bones to make needles. They were boneheads, but they make for fine tools.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [Her grins widens as she’s waiting for your reaction]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You can see she’s full of rage. All these years of searching recognition have taken a toll on her mind. But beneath the waves of anger that emanate from her, you feel something else. Maybe a kind of… Sadness?]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: You’re admirative
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: You’re afraid
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You feel a cold shiver running down your spine. Sweat dripping from your jaws. But interestingly, at the same time… A thrill ? You weirdo.] I get what you say. Battle is our natural way of life and death is part of that endless cycle.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You see her noding] Nevertheless I see the change we’re bringing right now as an another step in this cycle. I don’t want to keep doing what I’m doing till I die. Korm will laugh at my face when facing him in the halls of Vallhala.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She frowns but wait for you to continue (provisoire)] I am a thane of [TRIBE NAME] for Trarg’s sake ! [You slam your fist against the table, prompting reactions from the nearby patrons cowering on their chair]
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You feel the sudden urge to spew. When you look at Agna’s face, you see her teeth. They seem so sharp. You gulp. She notices. You can almost touch her disappointment.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: And what is your occupation during this time of peace ?
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: The holy hammer
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: The mighty pole
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: The sacred calice
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: I am the Bearer of the Holy Hammer. I work at the forge.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: I am the Holder of the Mighty Pole. I use flies to fish. That’s it.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [Straightening up, gloating] I am the Keeper of the Sacred Chalice of Divine Bowels. I work for the Sages and the good of the rituals.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She nods silently] I see. That is an honorable position for a non-warrior. I guess you must be working with my mother, Dagna. But I wouldn’t boast if I were you
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: A fisherman… That’s… unusual. But I guess you tried to keep fighting in the core of your job. In your own way…
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She gives you a disgusted look] That’s a demeaning position. Wiping the arse of these old goats all day must be testing for a former warrior. I’m sure you could have found better. Or at least I hope so.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: I pray for it to end
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: It will end
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: How dare you ?
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: A wish I share.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: That’s a wise way to see it.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: I won’t let you diminish me nor the housewives. They work twice more as you lazy baboon. [She says while standing up slowly, reaching for her sword. You begin to understand that it’s time for you to leave if you want to keep your head. (A part) Don’t insult the barbarian lady with a double-handed sword, you fool. In fact, don’t insult women. At. All.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She rises, drinking the remaining beer in one noisy gulp, with an half-smile on her face, she drops coins on the table and glance at you with a look of, what seems to be, surprise and almost satisfaction] I must go now, I have… responsibilities I suppose, knitting is a never-ending task.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She sighs but regains her composure] Let’s share an another beer later, [PP] !
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You’ve decided to meet Agna at the Axe and Roses again. You’ve arrived early. Seated at the back of the tavern, you enjoy the last rays of the setting sun, a pint of fresh beer in your hand. The heavy door of the pub opens in a loud crack. ]
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [There she is. And she’s not happy. When Agna sees you, she walks to you and grabs you by your shirt. She holds you so close you can sent her breath. Blueberry and a hint of peppermint.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: You ! I should never have gave you my trust. I’m sure it is you who have stolen my needles. I NEED some. Badly. Do you really wish to become my next tool ? I’ll carve your bones with care.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She notices your surprise. You obviously don’t understand why she’s enraged, your widen eyes and your, unwittingly of course, shaking limbs speak for you.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: You act strong
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: You’re afraid
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: (You look her straight in the eyes) What is your problem, Agna, daughter of Dagna ? I didn’t steal anything from you.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You try to collect yourself and fail. Miserably. Looking for backups, you realize no one will even stand up to her. You answer in a trembling voice] What…? I’m… What are you talking…?
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She stops, confused. Looking at you glassy-eyed, she, a second later, seems to get a hold of herself. Nevertheless she spits at you]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [It seems to deepen her anger, she’s now shouting, spluttering all over your face. As usual patrons are cowering, almost as a reflex.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: Of course you’d say that. As everyone else would. Bunch of weak-pantied male ! Always lying, always hiding when you should woman-up. But that’s the way of your clan right ? Hiding behind your axe to compensate your lack of courage, even for the most futile of things ! I had to work twice as hard as the men, just because I lacked the balls they said, laughing their asses off.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: Oh I sweated, in the forge, in the stables, on the battlefield ! I annihilated the Stone Prophet Clan, by myself, bathing in the blood and screams of my enemies. And still, still they laughed, grinned when I was there, mocking me and my mother. Oh yes. Poor Dagna with her fatherless daughter, she needs to settle down, why not with Vortharg the smith apprentice or Enthek the little warrior ?
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: Judgement, rumors, sneaky vipers, I lived with it, with them all my life. And then, I picked up the sword. And they stopped laughing. Or I made them stop. From the poor little freak, I became the big scary one. I became the mountain of [CLAN NAME] but I never forgot my little sisters, I carried some of them with me here. I protected them when they were slaughtering us, my back is still carrying the scars of my fight.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: And you came and tell me, right in my eyes that I’ve been wronged ? I can’t tolerate it. I won’t tolerate it. [Her voice made the walls tremble, her roaring grew louder and louder, causing the other patrons to hide under the bar and the tables. In the end she sat on a nearby chair, exhausted radiating a mix of hate and a bit of sorrow, after pouring her heart out]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: You care
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: You defy her
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You are stunned. You look at her, speechless. Obviously. You’re facing 6’3” barbarian woman with a sword at her side, you better be careful with your next words. You answer very cautiously] I… Did not think about it. Listen, Agna. I am sorry. I didn’t really know about your story, until now. I can’t fix the past, but I can help you now, if you will. Do you want me to go look for the ones who stole your needles with you ?
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: I don’t know how to carve on bones, but maybe you could teach me ? I didn’t really know about your story, until now. I can’t fix the past, but I can help you now, if you will. Do you want me to go look for the ones who stole your needles with you ? I don’t know how to carve on bones, but maybe you could teach me ?
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: You look at her, contemptuous. No one and no thing dares to move or breathe.] Are you finished ? I thought you were a kind of barbarian queen and in the end you’re just weeping your strength away. That’s a shame.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She looks at you, surprised. A faint blush is colouring her cheekbones. She grabs her tankard, hastily swallowing the last of her beer. When she slams her mug on the table, she’s regained her composure. She looks at you intensely. In her eyes you can see something new. Something like gratitude.] Yes, [PP]. Yes, I would appreciate that. Let’s go.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [She looks at you with a disappointed look. Too tired to shout again. Her hair falling pathetically around her head, her eyes having lost their sparkles.] You should get out, return to whatever activity allow you some joy. In a way, I pity you.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You stand up, everyone is looking at you, some with a discontented look on their face. You walk proudly, flexing your muscle. A part of you seems to think that you’ve missed something but, blinded by your ego, you’re thinking that you’ve just escaped from some bad joke. You are a terrible human being.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You come back to the tavern the next day, arm in arm with Agna, bursting with laughter while drinking pint after pint, re-telling again and again the story of the last night. Surprisingly even patrons come to see the both of you, and some, the brave ones, even ask Agna some details about the fight. At first she answers begrudgingly, but more and more came and she finds herself in middle of a crowd.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: The story, quite familiar within the barbarians, become at each iteration more and more of an epic, from a handful of foes it became the tale of you and her facing armies, slaying monstrous beasts.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: Then, the first one begin to fall from the beer, then the others start to leave. It’s the middle of the day but you [PP] and Agna are alone in this rascal den, the soft rays of the sun heating your skin, the beer rushing through their veins. She looks at you. Almost… happy ? You look at each other for a long time, without a word. Then she lowers her head and mutters]
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: You… I… I’d… I’d want to thank you.
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: [You glance at her, a smile beginning to appear on your face before realising she’s dead serious. You smile fades away. Looking at her deep brown eyes, the importance of this phrase strikes you.]
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [Looking at her amused above your beer] Thanks to you, too. You were amazingly graceful with that sword. But you didn’t need to kick the chief’s head in his subordinate’s face, that maybe was a tad overkill…
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: [Her roaring laugh exploded. A few hours ago it would have startled you, now your smile broadens just hearing it. She’s laughing for a few minutes before stopping, tears flowing down her cheeks. With the rumbling noise ending she hits your shoulder]
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: You’re terrible. I’m trying to be serious, leave the banter at bay this time. Really when I said thank you I meant it. You are the first person to help me in a long time. And it seems we have the same hobbies. [She says grinning tapping the pommel of her sword with her finger]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: Maybe we should, you know... Get to know each other a little bit more ? [Her voice lingers on the “know’, and… you may be dreaming but… Have you caught her blushing for a second ? Well. Maybe it’s something to consider...]
DialogueLine.speaker: Agna

DialogueLine.dialogue: I am doing my best to help the clan. But I am praying to Korm everyday that he’ll put that time of peace to an end.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: I don’t like what I do, but it’s temporary. I won’t let it define me.
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi

DialogueLine.dialogue: I do what I have to do. At least I don’t have the hobbies of a candy-coated housewife !
DialogueLine.speaker: Moi
